headline.main: THE UNION FOREVER!; Immense Demonstration in this City. THE ENTIRE POPULATION IN THE STREETS. Over One Hundred Thousand People at Union-square. The Metropolis Streaming with Banners and Streamers. Processions, Speeches and Resolutions. LETTER FROM ARCHBISHOP HUGHES. Addresses by John A. Dix, Daniel S. Dickinson, Wm. M. Evarts, Senator Baker, Henry J. Raymond, Moses H. Grinnell Wm. F. Havemeyer, Fernando Wood, Wm. Curtis Noyes, Rich'd O'Gorman, D.D. Field, Hiram Ketchum, John Cochrane, and Others. STAND NO. 1. THE APPROACH OF MAJOR ANDERSON, SPEECH OF DR. SPRING. RECEPTION OF HON. JOHN A. DIX. SPEECH OF HON. JOHN A DIX. ANOTHER HERO FROM FORT SUMTER LETTER OF ARCHBISHOP HUGHES. THE UNION MASS MEETING. THE SECOND STAND. SPEECH OF RICHARD O'GORMAN. SPEECH OF PROF. MITCHELL. STAND No. 3. THE FOURTH STAND. SPEECH OF ROYAL PHELPS. PRAYER. WM. CURTIS MOVES SPEECH. SPEECH OF SENATOR SPINOLA. SPEECH OF DAVID DUDLEY FIELD. STAND NO. 5. PROCEEDINGS OUTSIDE.
LAW REPORTS.; United States District Court. Before Judge Shipman. FORFEITURE OF SEAMEN'S WAGES MUTINY

docs.snippet: This gallant officer arrived, with his command in this City yesterday, and was received with a hearty and enthusiastic welcome. Thousands and tens of thousands of our citizens crowded the streets through which he passed, and lingered for hours in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: This gallant officer arrived, with his command in this City yesterday, and was received with a hearty and enthusiastic welcome. Thousands and tens of thousands of our citizens crowded the streets through which he passed, and lingered for hours in the vicinity of his hotel, eager to see him and assure him of the universal applause which greets his gallant and noble defence of the Stars and Strives.

headline.main: THE HEROES OF FORT SUMTER.; Return of the Baltic Names of those Wounded by the Bombardment Scenes and Incidents of the Arrival Enthusiasmof the People Salutes from the Battery and theShipping. PUBLIC ENTHUSIASM MOVEMENTS OF MAJOR ANDERSON.

docs.lead_paragraph: The steamship Baltic, Capt. FLETCHER, which left Charleston Bar at 8 P.M. on the 8th inst., came up to the City and anchored off the Battery at 1 P. M., to-day. She had flying from her mainmast head the flag which lately waved over Fort Sumter, and at her foremast-head the flag which was hauled down when Fort Moultrie was evacuated.

docs.snippet: There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious associations in all other minds....

headline.main: THE FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE OF THE NURSERY.; The following is an extract from a letter written by Rev. C.Z. Weiser, to the "German Reformed Messenger," Chambersburgh, Penn. BENEFACTRESS.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious associations in all other minds. Whatever no- tions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse the GOOD Nurse the BEST Nurse.

docs.snippet: The Assembly met with a slim attendance. Immediately after the reading of the Journal, the $3,000,000 War bill came down from the Senate with amendments, made by that body.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Assembly met with a slim attendance. Immediately after the reading of the Journal, the $3,000,000 War bill came down from the Senate with amendments, made by that body.

docs.snippet: The Senate met at 10 o'clock to-day, with a full attendance.

headline.main: IMPORTANT FROM ALBANY.; ADJOURNMENT OF THE LEGISLATURE SINE DIE. The War Bill Signed by the Governor. SENATE.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate met at 10 o'clock to-day, with a full attendance.

docs.snippet: It was reported in Washington, yesterday morning, that martial law would be proclaimed in the District of Columbia, at noon. Such, it appears, was the President's intention, but he subsequently came to the conclusion, in view of the excellent order...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was reported in Washington, yesterday morning, that martial law would be proclaimed in the District of Columbia, at noon. Such, it appears, was the President's intention, but he subsequently came to the conclusion, in view of the excellent order which everywhere prevailed, and the marked sympathy for the Government which was generally ...
